title: How to Make the Best Stovetop Hamburgers

steps.title: Buy quality beef with a meat-to-fat ratio of 80/20.
steps.content: Buy quality beef with a meat-to-fat ratio of 80/20. Lean meat above 90% tends not to cook as well as beef with a slightly higher fat content. It’s okay to go a little leaner than 80/20 with beef that’s 85/15, but 80/20 typically gives you the tender, juicy burgers you’re looking for. [1] X Research source Buy freshly ground beef from the butcher counter for the best quality meat.

steps.title: Separate the beef into patties that are about 6 ounces (1.7 hg) apiece.
steps.content: Separate the beef into patties that are about 6 ounces (1.7 hg) apiece. Use a kitchen scale to measure out the beef into equal sizes. If you don’t have a kitchen scale, just divide the beef into equal-looking sections based on the amount of meat you have. For instance, 1.5 pounds (0.68 kg) of meat usually makes about 4 patties.

steps.title: Form the meat into 1-inch (2.5 cm) thick patties with your hands.
steps.content: Form the meat into 1-inch (2.5 cm) thick patties with your hands. Handle the meat gently, as the less you mess with it, the more tender it will be. To form the patty, simply roll the meat into a light ball with your hands. Then, press it down onto a plate or between your hands to flatten it into a circle. [2] X Research source You don't need to mash the patties or knead the meat. That tends to make the meat tough.

steps.title: Press a dimple into the middle of each patty with your finger.
steps.content: Press a dimple into the middle of each patty with your finger. Patties tend to puff up and create a dome shape when they cook. To keep them flat , push your thumb into the middle of each patty, creating a dimple. [3] X Research source However, if you prefer your patties to puff up, simply skip this step.

steps.title: Put the patties in the refrigerator for 20 minutes.
steps.content: Put the patties in the refrigerator for 20 minutes. Cover the patties up with plastic wrap and let them chill in the refrigerator. Chilling the patties helps them stay together better when you cook them. It also prevents the center from cooking too quickly. [4] X Research source Don't leave the patties out at room temperature, as that encourages bacteria to grow.

steps.title: Heat a cast iron skillet over medium-high heat.
steps.content: Heat a cast iron skillet over medium-high heat. Place the skillet on the stove and turn the burner on medium-high. Letting the pan heat up before you put the burger patties in helps prevent them from sticking and gives your burgers a beautiful sear. To test if the skillet is hot enough, splash in a little bit of water. If the water instantly sizzles, the pan is likely ready for your patties. [5] X Research source Cast iron skillets are generally best for cooking burgers, but griddle pans or other non-stick pans work great.

steps.title: Salt the patties before you place them in the skillet.
steps.content: Salt the patties before you place them in the skillet. Salting your patties when you initially form them pulls out moisture, which can lead to dry hamburgers. So, sprinkle your patties with a pinch of salt on each side before you put them in the pan. This gives them a nice seasoning and helps retain their juiciness. [6] X Research source If you want more flavor, season your hamburgers with black pepper, paprika, garlic, cumin, or whatever your heart desires.

steps.title: Place the patties in the hot skillet.
steps.content: Place the patties in the hot skillet. Gently and carefully set each patty in the skillet, being sure to avoid any popping grease as you do. If your skillet is hot enough, the patties will sizzle and make noise as soon as they're inside. They’re already starting to create a nice, seared crust. [7] X Research source If your patties aren’t sizzling as soon as you drop them in your skillet, turn up the heat. Use a splatter screen or drop the patties in the skillet with long tongs to avoid popping grease from the pan.

steps.title: Cook the patties over medium-high heat for 2-4 minutes, then flip them.
steps.content: Cook the patties over medium-high heat for 2-4 minutes, then flip them. Using high heat crisps and cooks the patty quickly. After letting the first side cook for 2-4 minutes, flip the patty. When you flip it, you’ll see that it has a nice, golden-brown crust. That’s the delicious crunch you’re aiming for, even if you prefer the inside of your patty to be rare to medium. [8] X Research source Use a thin spatula for flipping. A thin spatula makes it easier to get under the seared crust. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Cook the patties for no more than 10 minutes.
steps.content: Cook the patties for no more than 10 minutes. Your hamburgers will usually be well-done after cooking them for 10 minutes, or 5 minutes on each side. If you want your patties medium or medium-rare, cook them for about 6 to 8 minutes, or 3 to 4 minutes on each side. [10] X Research source Use a meat probe to check the hamburger’s internal temperature and ensure that it’s done to your liking. The Food and Drug Administration recommends cooking ground beef until it's 160 °F (71 °C), which is when it's considered well done. This kills any bacteria inside the burger. If you prefer your burger rare, medium-rare, or medium, there is a risk that bacteria like E. coli haven't been killed (though, this is rare). [11] X Trustworthy Source US Food and Drug Administration U.S. government agency responsible for promoting public health Go to source

steps.title: Push broken patty pieces back together.
steps.content: Push broken patty pieces back together. Sometimes, your patty will fall apart as it cooks. If one of yours does, just use the spatula to move and squish the broken pieces back together. Letting it cook that way for a few minutes helps the pieces stay intact. [12] X Research source Adding cheese on top of your patties is a tasty way to help your patties stay together.

steps.title: Add slices of cheese on top of your patties in the last minute of cooking.
steps.content: Add slices of cheese on top of your patties in the last minute of cooking. If you want to make a cheeseburger, just cut up some thin slices of your favorite cheese. When your patties have 1 minute left to cook, place the cheese directly on top of the burgers. Cover the pan with a lid or aluminum foil to reflect the heat back down on the cheese and help it melt. [13] X Research source Many kinds of cheese work well with hamburgers. American cheese, cheddar, Gouda, Monterrey jack, blue cheese, and Swiss are all delicious choices. To get your cheese to melt quicker, add a small dash of water to the pan. The water will instantly turn into steam, which helps melt the cheese.

steps.title: Remove the patties from the stove and serve them on buns.
steps.content: Remove the patties from the stove and serve them on buns. Turn off the heat and use a spatula to take the patties out of the skillet. Place them on a plate to cool down for a minute, or set them directly onto buns. Add any extra toppings you like, and dig in! [14] X Research source Spice up your burger with condiments like mayonnaise, ketchup, mustard, or bbq sauce. Toppings like raw or grilled onions, lettuce, tomato, grilled mushrooms, cooked bacon, and avocado slices add extra flavor and texture to your burger. Dial up your hamburgers even more by toasting the buns in a skillet, in the oven, or in the toaster.
